items.standfirst: Police say 53-year-old Elmars Kalejs was found lying next to his car with serious head injuries in April.
items.content: Murder charges have been laid over the mystery death of a grandfather in a Bedfordale carpark.Police say 53-year-old Elmars Kalejs was found lying next to his car with serious head injuries in April.He was rushed to Royal Perth Hospital but eventually died from his injuries at the end of June.READ MORE: Families rattled after teens allegedly broke into their homes to steal carsFollowing his death, his daughter made an emotional plea for information to give the family closure around the grandfather's death.Homicide Squad have now charged a 48-year-old man from Cloverdale.He'll front court tomorrow.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

• The case has drawn significant attention due to the individuals involved.

clusters.title: Tinkering at the edges of productivity may cost more than we realise

items.title: Tinkering at the edges of productivity may cost more than we realise
items.standfirst: As the roundtable nears, the list of ideas has grown longer, more ambitious and often contradictory.
items.content: As the roundtable nears, the list of ideas has grown longer, more ambitious and often contradictory.

clusters.ai_summary:
• The list of productivity ideas has grown longer and more ambitious.
• Many of the ideas presented are often contradictory in nature.

clusters.title: Dietitians warn creatine craze is not for everyone
clusters.neutral_headline: Dietitians Warn About Creatine Craze and Product Quality

items.title: Dietitians warn creatine craze is not for everyone
items.standfirst: Health experts say we are in the midst of a creatine craze, but independent tests show some expensive gummy brands contain next to no creatine.
items.content: Health experts say we are in the midst of a creatine craze, but independent tests show some expensive gummy brands contain next to no creatine.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Health experts are warning about the current creatine craze.
• Independent tests show some gummy brands contain little creatine.
• The tests were conducted on some expensive gummy brands.
• The experts are concerned about the quality of some products.
• The focus is on the potential risks of unregulated supplements.
